categories.description: Palantir is a seeing-stone used by Sauron and others in Middle-earth to communicate and observe distant places.
Palantir Technologies is a data analytics company founded by Peter Thiel specializing in big data and intelligence.
Palantir Technologies epitomizes Silicon Valley's tendency to adopt fantasy names for surveillance capitalism ventures.
Mithril is the precious 'true-silver' metal in Middle-earth, lighter than silk yet harder than steel. Frodo's mithril coat saved his life in Moria.
Mithril.js is a lightweight JavaScript SPA framework for building front-end applications.
D&D uses 'Mithral' (not Mithril) as its magical silver metal. The spelling difference distinguishes Tolkien's original from D&D's adaptation.
Shadowfax is the lord of all horses in Middle-earth, ridden by Gandalf the White and said to understand human speech.
Andúril is Aragorn's reforged sword 'Flame of the West', originally the shards of Narsil that cut the Ring from Sauron's hand.
Anduril Industries is a defense technology company founded by Palmer Luckey, creating autonomous weapons systems.
Anduril represents Silicon Valley's VC-backed militarization wrapped in Tolkien branding.
The Silmarils are three jewels created by Fëanor containing the light of the Two Trees of Valinor, central to The Silmarillion.
Arwen Undómiel is the Elven princess, daughter of Elrond, who chose mortality to be with Aragorn.
Galadriel is the Lady of Lothlórien, one of the most powerful Elves in Middle-earth who resisted the temptation of the Ring.
Galadriel appears in MTG's Tales of Middle-earth set as 'Galadriel, Light of Valinor' and other variants.
Númenor was the great island kingdom of Men, destroyed when they tried to invade the Undying Lands, Atlantis-like in its fall.
Sauron is the Dark Lord, creator of the One Ring, and main antagonist of Lord of the Rings who manifests as a lidless eye.
Sauron appears as multiple cards in MTG's Tales of Middle-earth set, including 'Sauron, the Lidless Eye'.
Saruman the White was the head of the wizard order who was corrupted by Sauron and bred Uruk-hai at Isengard.
Don't confuse Saruman with Dooku - Christopher Lee played both, but they're from different franchises entirely.
Legolas is the Elven prince of Mirkwood and member of the Fellowship, known for his superhuman archery and impossible physics-defying moves.
Legolas appears in MTG's Tales of Middle-earth set as 'Legolas, Master Archer' and 'Legolas, Counter of Kills'.
Gimli is the Dwarf warrior of the Fellowship, son of Glóin, and friend of Legolas despite the traditional Elf-Dwarf enmity.
Gimli appears in MTG's Tales of Middle-earth set as 'Gimli, Counter of Kills' and partners with Legolas.
Though Tolkien drew from Norse mythology for Dwarf names, Gimli is his creation, not a figure from the Eddas.
Elrond Half-elven is the Lord of Rivendell who hosted the Council that formed the Fellowship and possesses great healing powers.
Elrond appears in MTG's Tales of Middle-earth set as 'Elrond, Lord of Rivendell' and 'Elrond, Master of Healing'.
The Balrog is an ancient demon of shadow and flame that Gandalf faced in Moria, famously told 'You shall not pass!'
D&D has Balors, not Balrogs. TSR renamed them after legal threats from the Tolkien estate - the similarity is intentional but legally distinct.
Warhammer has Bloodthirsters as their fire demons of Khorne, not Balrogs. Similar aesthetic but different universe.
The Nazgûl are the nine Ringwraiths, once mortal kings enslaved by Sauron's rings and led by the Witch-king of Angmar.
Nazgûl is an Italian black metal band formed in 1992, taking their name from Tolkien's wraiths.
Glamdring is Gandalf's Elven sword, also known as 'Foe-hammer', found in a troll hoard alongside Orcrist and Sting.
Morgoth was the first Dark Lord in Tolkien's legendarium, Sauron's master, who stole the Silmarils and corrupted Middle-earth.
Morgoth is a German death metal band formed in 1985, named after Tolkien's ultimate villain.
Shelob is the giant spider who guards the pass of Cirith Ungol and attacked Frodo, offspring of Ungoliant.
D&D has its own giant spiders and Lolth the Spider Queen, but Shelob is purely Tolkien. The spider aesthetic overlaps but the names don't.
Éowyn is the shieldmaiden of Rohan who slew the Witch-king of Angmar, famously declaring 'I am no man!'
Faramir is Boromir's younger brother and Captain of Gondor who helped Frodo on his quest and resisted the Ring's temptation.
Boromir is the son of Denethor and member of the Fellowship who was corrupted by the Ring but redeemed himself protecting Merry and Pippin.
Isildur cut the Ring from Sauron's hand but refused to destroy it, leading to his death and the Ring's loss for millennia.
Treebeard (Fangorn) is the oldest Ent who led the attack on Isengard, speaks slowly, and shepherds the forests.
D&D has Treants as tree creatures, but Treebeard is Tolkien's Ent. D&D adapted the concept but not this specific name.
Sméagol was a Hobbit-like creature corrupted into Gollum by the One Ring after murdering his friend Déagol to possess it.
Orcrist is Thorin Oakenshield's Elven sword, known as the 'Goblin-cleaver', twin to Glamdring.
Narsil was the sword that cut the Ring from Sauron's hand, later reforged as Andúril for Aragorn.
Lothlórien is the golden forest realm ruled by Galadriel and Celeborn where the Fellowship received gifts.
Rivendell (Imladris) is Elrond's hidden valley sanctuary in the Misty Mountains where the Council of Elrond took place.
Mirkwood is the great forest home to Wood-elves, corrupted by Sauron's influence and filled with giant spiders.
Mordor is Sauron's realm of shadow where Mount Doom lies and the Ring was forged. One does not simply walk into it.
Despite both being volcanic evil lairs, Mordor is not Mustafar. Different dark lords, different franchises.
Celeborn is Galadriel's husband and Lord of Lothlórien, though often overshadowed by his powerful wife.
Thranduil is Legolas's father and King of the Woodland Realm in Mirkwood, featured prominently in The Hobbit.
Denethor II was the Steward of Gondor who went mad from using a palantír and seeing Sauron's power, ultimately self-immolating.
Glorfindel is a mighty Elf-lord who helped Frodo escape the Nazgûl to Rivendell, so powerful his presence shines like light.
Théoden was the King of Rohan who led the charge at Pelennor Fields after being freed from Saruman's influence by Gandalf.
Éomer is Éowyn's brother and Marshal of the Riddermark who became King of Rohan after Théoden's death.
Anakin Skywalker is the Chosen One prophesied to bring balance to the Force who became Darth Vader.
Padmé Amidala is the Queen and Senator of Naboo, mother of Luke and Leia, who died of sadness (somehow).
Qui-Gon Jinn is the Jedi Master who discovered Anakin Skywalker on Tatooine and was killed by Darth Maul.
Obi-Wan Kenobi is the legendary Jedi Master who trained both Anakin and Luke Skywalker, and master of the high ground.
Yoda is the 900-year-old Jedi Grand Master known for his wisdom and unique speech pattern ('Do or do not, there is no try').
Despite Star Wars' popularity, Yoda has never appeared in Super Smash Bros. He did appear in Soul Calibur IV though.
Mace Windu is a Jedi Master and member of the Jedi Council who wields a purple lightsaber and was betrayed by Anakin.
Palpatine is the Sith Lord Darth Sidious who manipulated his way to becoming Emperor and creator of the Galactic Empire.
Despite the similar sound to 'Palantir', Palpatine is Star Wars, not Tolkien. One's an evil emperor, the other's a seeing stone.
Count Dooku is a former Jedi who became the Sith Lord Darth Tyranus and led the Separatists during the Clone Wars.
General Grievous is the cyborg Supreme Commander of the Separatist Droid Army who collects lightsabers and coughs constantly.
Kylo Ren is Ben Solo's dark side identity, grandson of Darth Vader, prone to throwing tantrums and smashing consoles.
Ahsoka Tano is a Togruta former Jedi Padawan of Anakin Skywalker who left the Order and became a key figure in the Rebellion.
Grogu is a Force-sensitive youngling of Yoda's species, found by Din Djarin, popularly known as 'Baby Yoda'.
Sounds like a Pokémon name, but Grogu is 'Baby Yoda' from The Mandalorian, not a pocket monster you can catch.
Din Djarin is a Mandalorian bounty hunter who becomes Grogu's guardian and speaks the famous line 'This is the Way'.
Grand Admiral Thrawn is a Chiss tactical genius serving the Galactic Empire, known for his brilliant military strategies and art appreciation.
Grand Moff Tarkin is the Imperial officer who commanded the first Death Star and ordered Alderaan's destruction.
Jabba the Hutt is a powerful crime lord operating from Tatooine who enslaved Leia and was strangled by her.
Boba Fett is a legendary bounty hunter and unaltered clone of Jango Fett who survived the Sarlacc pit.
Chewbacca is a Wookiee warrior and Han Solo's co-pilot and best friend who communicates through growls and roars.
Lando Calrissian is a gambler, smuggler, and former Baron Administrator of Cloud City who betrayed then helped Han Solo.
Tatooine is the desert planet with twin suns where Luke Skywalker was raised and Anakin was enslaved.
Coruscant is the city-covered planet that served as capital of the Republic and Empire, a massive ecumenopolis.
Naboo is a lush planet home to humans and the amphibious Gungans, where the Battle of Naboo took place.
Mustafar is a volcanic planet where Anakin Skywalker was defeated by Obi-Wan and transformed into Darth Vader.
Hoth is the frozen ice planet where the Rebel Alliance established Echo Base, attacked by AT-AT walkers.
Dagobah is the swamp planet where Yoda lived in exile and trained Luke in the ways of the Force.
Endor is the forest moon inhabited by Ewoks where the second Death Star was destroyed in the Battle of Endor.
Bespin is the gas giant planet where Cloud City floats in the atmosphere, site of Han Solo's carbonite freezing.
Kashyyyk is the forested homeworld of the Wookiees, with massive wroshyr trees and multiple canopy layers.
Mandalore is the homeworld of the Mandalorian warrior culture, known for beskar armor and fierce combat traditions.
Mandalore is Star Wars, not Warhammer. The Space Wolves are Warhammer's viking warriors, not Mandalorians.
Alderaan was Princess Leia's peaceful homeworld, destroyed by the Death Star as a demonstration of Imperial power.
Jakku is the desert junkyard planet where Rey grew up scavenging from crashed Star Destroyers.
Kyber crystals are Force-attuned crystals that power lightsabers and were used in the Death Star's superlaser.
Holocrons are ancient data storage devices containing Jedi or Sith knowledge, accessible only to Force users.
Bacta is a healing substance used in medical tanks to treat injuries, famously used to heal Luke after Hoth.
The Sarlacc is a large omnivorous creature that digests prey over thousands of years in its pit on Tatooine.
Rancors are large predatory reptiles, one was kept as a pet by Jabba the Hutt beneath his palace.
Ewoks are small furry sentient beings native to the forest moon of Endor who helped destroy the second Death Star.
Wookiees are tall, hairy sentient beings from Kashyyyk known for strength, loyalty, and pulling people's arms out of sockets when losing.
Twi'leks are a humanoid species with distinctive head-tails called lekku, often victimized by slavery in the galaxy.
Zabraks are a humanoid species with vestigial horns, including Darth Maul and other Force-sensitive individuals.
The Sith are an order of Force users who embrace the dark side, following the Rule of Two established by Darth Bane.
The Jedi are an order of Force users who serve as peacekeepers of the galaxy, adhering to a strict code and avoiding attachment.
Cirith Ungol is the spider pass into Mordor guarded by Shelob, where Frodo was captured by orcs.
Cirith Ungol is a classic American heavy metal band formed in 1972, named after the Tolkien location.
Isengard is Saruman's fortress with the tower of Orthanc, destroyed by the Ents in their march.
Isengard is a Norwegian black metal project by Fenriz of Darkthrone, named after Saruman's stronghold.
Carach Angren is Sindarin for 'Iron Jaws', a fortified pass into Mordor in Tolkien's Middle-earth.
Carach Angren is a Dutch symphonic black metal band that uses Tolkien's Sindarin name for their theatrical horror metal.
Bossk is a Trandoshan bounty hunter who appears in The Empire Strikes Back among those hired by Vader.
Lobot is Lando Calrissian's cyborg aide with a computer headband in Cloud City, communicating through the city's systems.
Asajj Ventress is a Dathomirian dark side assassin from the Clone Wars series, apprentice to Count Dooku.
Sebulba is the Dug podracer who cheated against young Anakin in The Phantom Menace's Boonta Eve race.
Plo Koon is a Kel Dor Jedi Master and member of the Jedi Council who wears protective goggles and breather.
Gonk droids (GNK Power Droids) are walking battery units that make 'gonk' sounds, beloved for their simple existence.
Dengar is a human bounty hunter seen on Vader's Star Destroyer in The Empire Strikes Back, wrapped in bandages.
Tiamat is the five-headed dragon queen of evil chromatic dragons in D&D, representing the ultimate draconic threat.
Tiamat is a Legendary Creature card in MTG that tutors dragon cards, paying homage to D&D's dragon goddess.
Tiamat is a Swedish gothic/doom metal band formed in 1988, named after the Babylonian chaos goddess.
Bahamut is the platinum dragon god of justice in D&D, king of metallic dragons and eternal enemy of Tiamat.
Bahamut is a Legendary Creature card in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms, representing the noble dragon god.
Asmodeus is the archdevil ruler of the Nine Hells in D&D, lord of devils and master schemer.
Asmodeus appears in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms as 'Asmodeus the Archfiend', a black legendary creature.
Balduran was a legendary explorer and founder of the city of Baldur's Gate in the Forgotten Realms.
The Tarrasque is a legendary dinosaur-like monstrosity in D&D, considered nearly impossible to kill and awakening only to eat.
The Tarrasque is a legendary creature card in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms, depicting D&D's ultimate monster.
Mystra is the goddess of magic in the Forgotten Realms, keeper of the Weave through which all magic flows.
Vecna is a powerful lich who became a god, known for his Hand and Eye artifacts that grant terrible powers.
Vecna appears in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms as 'The Book of Vile Darkness' can create a Vecna token.
A Beholder is an iconic D&D monster - a floating orb with a central eye and eyestalks with magical rays, paranoid and xenophobic.
Beholders appear in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms set as creature cards, bringing D&D's iconic aberrations to Magic.
Illithids (Mind Flayers) are psionic aberrations with tentacled faces that consume brains and dominate minds.
Mind Flayers appear in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms set, bringing D&D's brain-eating horrors to Magic.
The Drow are dark elves who live in the Underdark, known for their worship of Lolth and matriarchal society.
Tolkien has no Drow - his dark elves are the Moriquendi who never saw the light of the Trees. The Drow concept is purely D&D.
Warhammer has Dark Elves (Druchii), but they're called that, not Drow. The term 'Drow' is specific to D&D.
A Lich is an undead spellcaster who achieved immortality by binding their soul to a phylactery through dark rituals.
Lich is a classic black enchantment card in MTG, and liches appear throughout Magic's multiverse as undead mages.
Warhammer has 'Liches' among the undead, particularly the Liche Priests of Khemri who maintain Tomb King armies.
Count Strahd von Zarovich is the vampire lord of Barovia in the classic D&D adventure Curse of Strahd.
Warhammer has its own vampires like Mannfred von Carstein, but Strahd is purely D&D. Different gothic vampire lords.
Mordenkainen is the legendary archmage from D&D's Greyhawk setting, namesake of famous spells like Mordenkainen's Magnificent Mansion.
Mordenkainen is a Legendary Creature in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms, bringing D&D's archmage to Magic.
Elminster Aumar is the Sage of Shadowdale, one of the most powerful wizards in the Forgotten Realms and Ed Greenwood's self-insert.
Acererak is a powerful demilich, creator of the Tomb of Horrors and Tomb of Annihilation dungeons designed to kill players.
Acererak the Archlich is a legendary creature in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms, venturing through dungeons.
Faerûn is the main continent of the Forgotten Realms campaign setting in D&D, home to Baldur's Gate and Waterdeep.
Netheril was an ancient magical empire with flying cities in the Forgotten Realms, destroyed by the folly of Karsus.
Thay is a magocracy ruled by the Red Wizards in the Forgotten Realms, known for necromancy and slave trade.
Lolth is the Spider Queen goddess of the Drow and Queen of the Demonweb Pits, demanding sacrifices and scheming.
Lolth is a Legendary Creature in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms, representing the Drow goddess.
Drizzt Do'Urden is the iconic dual-scimitar wielding Drow ranger who rejected his evil heritage, hero of R.A. Salvatore's novels.
Drizzt is a Legendary Creature in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms, representing D&D's most famous Drow.
The Underdark is a vast subterranean realm beneath Faerûn, home to Drow, Duergar, Illithids, and other creatures of darkness.
A Flumph is a friendly floating aberration that feeds on psionic energy - one of D&D's quirkiest and most beloved joke monsters.
Flumph appears in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms as a rare blue creature that draws cards for everyone.
A Gelatinous Cube is a transparent ooze that fills dungeon corridors, dissolving anything it engulfs while cleaning the passages.
Gelatinous Cube is a creature card in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms, digesting creatures it absorbs.
An Owlbear is an iconic D&D monster combining an owl's head with a bear's body, created by a mad wizard's experiment.
Owlbear is a creature card in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms set, adapting D&D's hybrid monster for Magic.
A Displacer Beast is a six-legged panther-like creature with tentacles that projects illusions of itself several feet away.
Displacer Beast is a creature card in MTG's Adventures in the Forgotten Realms with abilities reflecting its illusory displacement.
The Githyanki are a warrior race from the Astral Plane who ride red dragons and hunt Illithids, their former masters.
Githyanki appear in MTG's Commander Legends: Battle for Baldur's Gate set as creature cards with combat abilities.
The Githzerai are psionic monks living in Limbo, cousins and enemies of the Githyanki after their split from slavery.
Aboleths are ancient aquatic aberrations with perfect memory that predate the gods in D&D lore, enslaving entire civilizations.
Aboleth appears in MTG's Commander Legends: Battle for Baldur's Gate as 'Aboleth Spawn', referencing D&D's ancient horrors.
Kenku are raven-like flightless bird people who can only speak by mimicking sounds in D&D, cursed by their master.
Slaadi are chaotic frog-like aberrations from the plane of Limbo in D&D, reproducing through implanting eggs.
Demogorgon is the two-headed Prince of Demons, one of the most powerful demon lords in D&D, embodying madness and destruction.
Despite sounding Greek, Demogorgon is not from Greek mythology. It's a medieval manuscript error that became a fantasy staple.
Orcus is the demon prince of undeath in D&D, wielding his wand that can kill with a touch.
Orcus is the Roman god of the underworld and punisher of broken oaths, from which D&D's demon prince takes his name.
A Bulette is a shark-like burrowing monster in D&D, also called a 'landshark', created from plastic dinosaur toys.
Modrons are lawful clockwork beings from the plane of Mechanus in D&D, existing in a strict hierarchy from monodrone to primus.
Gondor is the southern kingdom of Men in Middle-earth, ruled from Minas Tirith by the line of stewards until Aragorn's return.
Aragorn is the heir of Isildur who becomes King of Gondor after the War of the Ring, also known as Strider.
Aragorn appears in MTG's Tales of Middle-earth set as multiple cards including 'Aragorn, the Uniter'.
Moria (Khazad-dûm) is the ancient Dwarf kingdom under the Misty Mountains where the Fellowship faced the Balrog.
Bolt Thrower is a weapon system in Warhammer 40K, a large ballistic device used by various factions.
Bolt Thrower was a British death metal band named after the Warhammer 40K weapon, known for their war-themed albums.
Chaos is the corrupting force in Warhammer, representing the four dark gods (Khorne, Nurgle, Tzeentch, Slaanesh) and their daemons.
Chaos (Χάος) was the primordial void that existed before all creation in Greek cosmogony, parent of Erebus and Nyx.
The Imperium of Man is the galaxy-spanning human civilization in Warhammer 40K, ruled by the God-Emperor from the Golden Throne.
Eldar (now rebranded as Aeldari) are the space elves of Warhammer 40K, an ancient dying race that birthed Slaanesh.
While 'Eldar' was borrowed from Tolkien (where it means ancient elves), Warhammer's Eldar are a completely separate space elf faction.
Orks are brutal green warriors in Warhammer, fungus-based creatures who believe red makes things go faster.
Orcs in D&D (sometimes spelled Ork in older editions) are savage humanoids who raid and pillage.
Tolkien uses 'Orc' with a C - the K spelling is specifically Warhammer's (and some other fantasy), not Tolkien's creation.
Sigmar is the human god-king who founded the Empire in Warhammer Fantasy, later returning as the God-King of Azyr.
Despite the Germanic sound, Sigmar is not from Norse mythology. He's a Warhammer-original deity inspired by Charlemagne.
Khorne is the Chaos God of blood, war, and skulls. Blood for the Blood God! Skulls for the Skull Throne!
Nurgle is the Chaos God of plague, decay, and disease, yet strangely jovial and affectionate to his followers.
Tzeentch is the Chaos God of change, magic, and scheming, the Architect of Fate who plots eternally.
Slaanesh is the Chaos God of excess and pleasure, born from Eldar decadence in a psychic cataclysm.
Tyranids are an extragalactic hive-mind species that consumes all biomass, leaving dead worlds in their wake.
Star Wars has similar insectoid aliens like Geonosians, but Tyranids are purely Warhammer 40K's Aliens-inspired swarm.
Necrons are ancient robotic undead who once ruled the galaxy, awakening from their tomb worlds after millions of years.
D&D has necromancers and undead, but 'Necrons' are specifically Warhammer 40K's robot skeleton faction.
T'au are a young species in Warhammer 40K promoting the Greater Good through diplomacy and advanced technology.
Tau (Τ, τ) is the 19th letter of the Greek alphabet, representing the 't' sound.
Primarchs are the twenty superhuman sons of the Emperor who led the Space Marine legions during the Great Crusade.
Horus was the Warmaster of the Imperium who betrayed the Emperor, sparking the Horus Heresy that shaped Warhammer 40K.
Horus is Egyptian, not Greek. He's the Egyptian falcon-headed god of the sky, son of Osiris and Isis.
Horus appears as a referenced deity in Assassin's Creed Origins, set in Ptolemaic Egypt, but the game isn't about him.
Magnus the Red is the Primarch of the Thousand Sons in Warhammer 40K, a powerful psyker who did nothing wrong (allegedly).
Mortarion is the Primarch of the Death Guard, now a Daemon Prince of Nurgle spreading pestilence across the galaxy.
Fulgrim is the Primarch of the Emperor's Children, now a Daemon Prince of Slaanesh obsessed with perfection and excess.
Angron is the Primarch of the World Eaters, a rage-filled Daemon Prince of Khorne with the Butcher's Nails implants.
Sounds like Aragorn, but Angron is a rage-fueled Daemon Primarch, not the noble heir of Isildur.
Roboute Guilliman is the Primarch of the Ultramarines and current Lord Commander, resurrected to lead the Imperium.
Space Marines are genetically-enhanced super soldiers defending the Imperium, also known as Adeptus Astartes.
The Warp is the chaotic parallel dimension in Warhammer 40K used for FTL travel, home to the Chaos Gods and daemons.
Daemons are Warp entities in Warhammer, manifestations of the Chaos Gods corrupting reality.
Demons in D&D are chaotic evil fiends from the Abyss, distinct from lawful evil devils.
Daemons are background processes in Unix-like operating systems that run without direct user interaction.
Inquisitors root out heresy in Warhammer, wielding absolute authority to purge corruption with extreme prejudice.
Inquisitors in D&D are divine warriors who hunt heretics and enemies of their faith, similar to paladins.
Commissars are political officers in the Imperial Guard who execute cowards to maintain morale. Summary execution is their specialty.
Rogue One and Rogue Squadron are Star Wars properties about rebels and pilots.
Rogue is a D&D class specializing in stealth, sneak attacks, and skillful cunning.
The Nissan Rogue is a compact crossover SUV popular in North America.
Rangers are the Dúnedain guardians in LOTR, protectors of the North led by Aragorn before he became king.
Ranger is a D&D class focused on wilderness survival, tracking, and archery with animal companions.
The Ford Ranger is a midsize pickup truck known for its durability and off-road capability.
Erebos is the god of the dead in MTG's Theros set, a black-aligned deity preventing escape from the underworld.
Erebos (Erebus) is the Greek primordial god of darkness, born from Chaos and brother of Nyx.
Sounds like Erebor, the Lonely Mountain of the dwarves, but Erebos is the Greek god of darkness - no dragon gold here.
Heliod is the god of the sun in MTG's Theros set, a white-aligned deity representing justice and law.
Heliod is based on Helios, the Greek sun god who drove the chariot of the sun across the sky daily.
Thassa is the god of the sea in MTG's Theros set, a blue-aligned deity controlling oceans and knowledge.
Thassa is based on Thalassa, the Greek primordial personification of the sea in cosmogony.
Purphoros is the god of the forge in MTG's Theros set, a red-aligned deity of craftsmanship and fire.
Purphoros is based on Hephaestus, the Greek god of blacksmiths, metalworking, and volcanic fire.
Nylea is the god of the hunt in MTG's Theros set, a green-aligned deity representing nature and the wild.
Nylea is based on Artemis, the Greek goddess of the hunt, wilderness, and wild animals.
Pestilence is an iconic black enchantment card in MTG that deals damage to all creatures and players.
Pestilence is a Dutch death metal band formed in 1986, pioneers of technical death metal.
Dismember is an instant removal spell in MTG with Phyrexian mana, allowing you to pay life instead of mana.
Dismember is a Swedish death metal band formed in 1988, known for their brutal grinding sound.
Iron Maiden is an artifact creature card in MTG that punishes players for having large hands.
Iron Maiden is the legendary British heavy metal band known for Eddie the Head and epic songs like 'The Trooper'.
Toralf is the god of fury in MTG's Kaldheim set, a red-aligned deity representing battle and thunder.
Toralf is based on Thor, the Norse god of thunder, lightning, and protection of mankind.
Alrund is the god of wisdom in MTG's Kaldheim set, a blue-aligned deity of knowledge and foresight.
Alrund is based on Odin, the Allfather and Norse god of wisdom, poetry, and magic who sacrificed his eye.
Valki is the god of lies in MTG's Kaldheim set, a black-aligned deity of deception and trickery.
Valki is based on Loki, the Norse trickster god known for shape-shifting and causing mischief among the gods.
Black Lotus is the most valuable and iconic card in MTG history, a 'Power Nine' artifact that generates three mana of any color.
Jace Beleren is one of the most iconic planeswalker characters in Magic: The Gathering, a blue-aligned mind mage.
Liliana Vess is a powerful necromancer planeswalker in Magic: The Gathering, black-aligned and dealing with demons.
Chandra Nalaar is a pyromancer planeswalker in Magic: The Gathering, red-aligned and wielding fire magic impulsively.
Chandra is NASA's X-ray space observatory, launched in 1999 and named after astrophysicist Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar.
